summary: A character reference letter written by Anne Holve, Ghislaine Maxwell's eldest sister, to Judge Alison J. Nathan in support of Maxwell's bail request. Holve attests to Maxwell's good character, family upbringing, and innocence of the charges, arguing she would not flee if granted bail.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The subject of the bail request and character reference. Her sister describes her upbringing, character, and asserts her innocence of the charges she faces.

persons.name: Anne Holve
persons.context: The author of the letter and Ghislaine Maxwell's eldest sister. She provides a personal character reference, describing their family upbringing and attesting to Maxwell's good character.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over Ghislaine Maxwell's case, to whom the character reference letter is addressed.

persons.name: Michael Maxwell
persons.context: Mentioned as the late eldest Maxwell sibling who died after a car accident in 1961.

connections.description: Anne Holve is Ghislaine Maxwell's eldest sister, writing a character reference letter in support of her bail request.
Ghislaine Maxwell's late eldest brother, who died in a car accident in 1961.

events.title: Bail request character reference submitted

events.title: Scheduled trial

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, NY 10007
Oxford (city, referenced as family home location)
North London (where Anne Holve has her therapy practice)
keyFacts: Anne Holve, Ghislaine Maxwell's eldest sister and a licensed psychotherapist, provides a character reference asserting Maxwell's innocence and good moral character.
Holve describes a difficult childhood with a domineering father but emphasizes the family's strong work ethic and moral values instilled in all siblings.
The letter states that Maxwell hosted nieces, nephews, and their friends at her home over the years, which is presented as evidence of her generosity.
Holve expresses "utter shock" at Maxwell's arrest and claims she never witnessed Maxwell be violent or sexually inappropriate with anyone.
The letter argues Maxwell would not flee if granted bail, as she is determined to fight the charges and clear her name in court.
